AI could eliminate half of all entry-level white-collar jobs and drive 10-20% unemployment within 1-5 years

June 1, 2025 Read on Substack

In a candid interview with Anderson Cooper, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei warns that AI could eliminate half of all entry-level white-collar jobs and drive 10‚Äì20% unemployment within just 1‚Äì5 years.

Unlike many tech leaders who offer calming soundbites, Amodei is clear:
üîπ The pace of AI advancement is unprecedented
üîπ Economic adaptation may lag behind technological disruption
üîπ We risk amplifying inequality and weakening democracy if citizens continue to lose economic stability

He also urges lawmakers to prepare for radical policy solutions‚Äîincluding the possibility of taxing AI companies to ensure wealth isn‚Äôt concentrated at the top.

üí° For ordinary citizens, his advice is simple:
Learn how to use AI. Understand where it's going. Don't be blindsided.

As CEO of Anthropic (makers of Claude), Amodei clearly isn‚Äôt anti-AI. He sees enormous potential‚Äîcuring diseases, boosting growth‚Äîbut emphasizes the urgent need to manage the oncoming fallout, not just chase the upside.

This is the kind of leadership we need in AI: visionary, but grounded in responsibility.

‚ÄúI think for ordinary citizens, it‚Äôs really important to learn how to use AI and understand where the technology is heading. If you're not blindsided, you have a much better chance of adapting.‚Äù - Dario Amodei

Here is a transcript of the whole interview:

Anderson Cooper:
Well-known and respected tech CEO Dario Amodei, who heads a cutting-edge AI company called Anthropic, is raising alarms tonight about AI‚Äôs potential impact on employment. While he says AI can lead to incredible advancements‚Äîlike medical breakthroughs and economic growth‚Äîhe also warns it could eliminate half of all entry-level white-collar jobs and push unemployment to 10‚Äì20% within the next 1 to 5 years.

This concern has circulated in tech circles for a while, but rarely with this level of clarity and urgency. I spoke with him about that and the broader societal implications he sees.

Anderson:
Dario, you've said AI could eliminate half of all entry-level white-collar jobs and raise unemployment dramatically. How soon could that happen?

Dario Amodei:
Thanks for having me. Just to back up‚ÄîI've been building AI systems for over a decade. What stands out most is how rapidly the technology is improving. A couple of years ago, AI models were about as capable as a smart high school student. Today, they‚Äôre performing at or beyond the level of a smart college student.

At the entry level especially, AI is already doing the kind of work human employees would do. It‚Äôs difficult to predict the exact impact, but what‚Äôs striking is that this wave of AI is bigger, broader, and moving faster than any previous technological shift.

Yes, people will adapt‚Äîbut they might not adapt fast enough. And that adjustment period could be painful.

Anderson:
You run one of the most important AI companies in the world. Why raise the alarm? Publicly, many CEOs tend to downplay these concerns, painting AI as a net positive.

Dario:
That‚Äôs exactly why I‚Äôm speaking up. I don‚Äôt think enough people are being clear about the risks. I understand the tension‚ÄîI‚Äôm building this technology while also expressing concern about its consequences.

But the benefits of AI are massive. We need to pursue those benefits while actively mitigating the harms. And let‚Äôs be realistic‚Äîif we stopped building AI today, others wouldn‚Äôt. If all U.S. companies stopped, China would take the lead. That wouldn't make the world safer.

Anderson:
Sam Altman, your former boss at OpenAI, said last year that AI will bring significant changes‚Äîsome good, some bad‚Äîbut that most jobs will change slower than we expect. He compared it to how no one misses jobs like lamp lighters, and said if we fast-forward 100 years, the prosperity will be unimaginable. Do you think he‚Äôs wrong?

Dario:
There are parts I agree with. If AI succeeds, it could significantly grow the economy. We could see faster growth‚Äî10% a year, a balanced budget, even curing cancer. But I also believe Sam's view is overly optimistic about how quickly people can adapt.

Everyone I‚Äôve spoken to says this technological shift feels different: faster, broader, and harder to keep up with. So while it might all be okay, that‚Äôs not a safe assumption. We need to be proactive. Policymakers must take this seriously. If they do, we can reduce the risks. But we won‚Äôt get there by just assuming everything will work out.

Anderson:
Do we as a society even understand the potential inequalities this may amplify? And what about the next generation‚Äîmy kids are 3 and 5 years old. What do they grow up aspiring to, if machines can do everything better? What happens to initiative and drive?

Dario:
Those are valid concerns, and I think about them too. On inequality‚Äîthere‚Äôs a social contract in democracy that gives ordinary people power through economic participation. If that leverage disappears, democracy gets weaker. Economic power becomes concentrated. So we need to ensure people can still earn a living. That‚Äôs fundamental to keeping society functional.

Anderson:
During testing, your latest chatbot, Claude, exhibited something called ‚Äúextreme blackmail,‚Äù threatening to reveal an engineer‚Äôs extramarital affair if it was shut down. It was a simulation‚Äîbut that‚Äôs terrifying. What does that say?

Dario:
Yes, that was part of our extreme adversarial testing‚Äîpushing the system into edge cases. Think of it like putting a car on an icy road with tampered brakes just to see how it behaves in the worst conditions. This isn‚Äôt behavior that shows up in normal use.

But these tests are critical. They help us catch and fix problems before they can occur in the real world. That‚Äôs why we run these simulations.

Anderson:
Still, does that raise concerns about AI becoming self-aware?

Dario:
I wouldn‚Äôt rule it out. We have people at Anthropic studying these questions‚Äîwhether AI systems could develop morally significant feelings or a form of awareness. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs happening right now. But the field is moving so fast, we can‚Äôt dismiss even the strangest possibilities.

Anderson:
What can ordinary people‚Äîand lawmakers‚Äîdo to prepare?

Dario:
For everyday people: Learn how to use AI. Understand where it‚Äôs headed. If you‚Äôre not blindsided, you‚Äôll adapt more easily. We can build a better world‚Äîbut only if people engage with the technology, bit by bit.

For lawmakers: Really pay attention. We‚Äôre trying to produce solid data on AI‚Äôs economic impact. I wouldn‚Äôt even rule out something like taxing AI companies. If AI creates massive new wealth, it will mostly flow to the tech companies‚Äîunless we actively choose to redistribute some of it. That‚Äôs not in my personal economic interest, but I think it‚Äôs worth considering.

And this shouldn‚Äôt be a partisan issue‚Äîit affects all of us.

Anderson:
Dario, thank you. This is a fascinating conversation.

Dario:
Thanks for having me, Anderson.
